author: Arsene Lupin III
subject: Re: FLCL and Copyrights
body:
> Furi Kuri, I think....

Or as I like to call it, "Fuli Culi." Someone picked
it up in the states (Synch Point, I think?), it's a
multi-part Gainax OAV series. The Japanese DVDs have
English subtitles from Volume 2 on. I have never seen
the series, and probably won't for a while. I'd love
to see this reference though, I'll have to put it on
my site, alongside the "Here is Greenwood" acting
scene.

About the copyright thing, here's something
interesting I've learned by reading up on the subject:

In America, "Arsene Lupin" has been public domain
since 1991.

"But then why did the 1991 and 1992 releases of
'Castle of Cagliostro' use 'Wolf?'"

Had anyone here read the article I posted about Carl
Macek, you would have read this little bit:

"The concept of 'wolf,' etc. was created to appease
the film's rights' holders who feared that there might
be some fallout from the "use' of Arsene Lupin - it
was a way to get the film into the market."

Robert Woodhead has also been known to agree with this
concept: Arsene is free game in America. The only real
preventions from calling him Lupin were the paranoid
rights-holders.

So basically, Daniel, what I think Manga meant was
that they probably spent a lot of time convincing TMS
to finally calm down about the whole paranoia thing
and permit them to use the Lupin name.
About dang time too. I dislike the name "Rupan."
Especially when you hear the name spoken by English
voice actors.

It's unfortunate that Manga did not use more common
sense in re-dubbing "Cagliostro."
